results.content:
Excellent course on building beautiful, responsive sites using HTML, CSS (with Bootstrap), and JavaScript (with jQuery)!

This course was VERY helpful in learning how to create professional looking websites. After completing the course I now feel empowered to create stunning websites for potential clients as a freelance web developer.

Drew covers a lot of the mainstream CSS and JavaScript components that a lot of big sites use these days. Every video was informative and engaging. 

The only thing that I feel could be improved is explaining more of the fundamentals behind jQuery, JavaScript and back-end development. These topics were never intended to be the focus of this course, but I feel as a new developer I would benefit immensely from more knowledge in those areas.

Overall great course Drew! Please create more courses in the future. I will definitely buy from you again!

This course was VERY helpful in learning how to create professional looking websites. After completing the course I now feel empowered to create stunning websites for potential clients as a freelance web developer.

Drew covers a lot of the mainstream CSS and JavaScript components that a lot of big sites use these days. Every video was informative and engaging.

results.content:
Overall I learned a lot of new things about CSS. I learned quite thoroughly about bootstrap navbar. How to apply neat animation on elements.

PROS:
The instructor went into the detail about how to use jumbotron, container and container fluid and explain in detail how each are different.

He went in to the detail about how to make that awesome stretched out background which to me was something new.

jquery file is included and the purpose of every line is explained thoroughly.

Overall the explanation is pretty clear. 

You can replicate most of the css and js files provided, plug and play using classes and some minor coding to solve repetitive design issues.

CONS:
Unfortunately the instructor did not delve much into bootstrap itself. There are many aspects about bootstrap for instance bootstrap utilities, modal, etc that was not even discussed in this course. I use those a lot in my projects. If you want to use those, you just need to figure it out yourself by reading the doc.

The animation classes and js files are prebuilt, pretty much plug and play. Which makes it easier for beginners, but not for an inquisitive learner who is eager to have a deeper understanding.

Last but not least, the good practice of proper indentation was not practiced throughout the course. Instead of indentation, the instructor uses comments. But when you miss one div tag, your web page will not render as shown by the instructor and you would need to figure out where you missed a <div> tag, and it can be really painful. Proper indentation would help.

This is my judgement and I am only until 50% of the course. I followed through all the assignments and my page won't render as shown because a div tag is missing and I still can't figure out which one.

response.content:
Hi Amri,
Thanks for leaving this feedback of your experience but I'm sorry the course wasn't more satisfactory for you. Your cons points are well taken and I'd like to address some of them here.
Some students may be looking for more of an introductory course rather than jumping right into building a website without knowing the framework, but the purpose of the course is to build a real world, working template in depth rather than build several small projects for example with more exposure to all of the Bootstrap Components. 
On the indentation note, I think you have a good point as I've put a container and row on the same indented line for example, but I decided to indent the theme the way I have to try to create the least confusion possible for a student when viewing the video. For example, if every element had it's own indentation preceding the next there wouldn't be much width left in the text editor for long enough lines of HTML to be a good teaching experience in my opinion.
On the interactive features of the theme, you are right on them being plug and play aside from JS for customizations to them. I would continue to stress the purpose of the course being to build a working theme rather than gain an in depth understanding of JS in this example.
I'm happy to help with the missing div you have if you'd like to send me a message or post a question in the Q/A section and thanks again for your thoughtful feedback!
-Drew

results.content:
This course is perfect for beginners, or someone who wants to quickly get up to speed on building their own Nuno-based web page. I originally dismissed it but after completion I understand its purpose and audience. 

The one critique I have was the transition to the PHP version was not as detailed as it should have been. The tutorial focused on the html versions exclusively and then suddenly the student is presented with finished PHP versions to be uploaded to Flywheel/MAMP. "Wait, what?" is the appropriate response. I would have thought conversion to PHP would have been addressed earlier, although it was addressed in lesson 59. Still, almost came across as an after-thought and I think some users would have liked to have gone through the HTML to PHP conversion process. 

Still, I think Drew knows his material and in the end I would give the course my highest recommendation. Lots of little tricks I will reference in the future.
results.content_html:
This course is perfect for beginners, or someone who wants to quickly get up to speed on building their own Nuno-based web page. I originally dismissed it but after completion I understand its purpose and audience.

The one critique I have was the transition to the PHP version was not as detailed as it should have been. The tutorial focused on the html versions exclusively and then suddenly the student is presented with finished PHP versions to be uploaded to Flywheel/MAMP. "Wait, what?" is the appropriate response. I would have thought conversion to PHP would have been addressed earlier, although it was addressed in lesson 59. Still, almost came across as an after-thought and I think some users would have liked to have gone through the HTML to PHP conversion process.

Still, I think Drew knows his material and in the end I would give the course my highest recommendation. Lots of little tricks I will reference in the future.

results.content: The course content is great, it is exactly what I was hoping for, but the presentation really needs a bit of a tweaking. The speech is clear, but it drives me nuts that the speaker speaks in disconnected sentences. It is really off putting  and immensely distracting when he leaves big pauses in the middle of sentences, between words, and causes the tone of the sentence to get lost. The result is that he sounds very unsure of what he's saying all the time, sentences aren't finished where or how they're supposed to more than a few times in each video, and when your'e trying to follow along with a jam packed coding video, the last thing you want to be doing is trying to allocate a lot of focus just to break down and reconstruct the speakers sentences into cohesive pieces that make a bit more sense. Again, the course is really good, I just find its really irritating to work through the videos in this way, its just so much extra head noise to deal with that it actually ends up exhausting you.

The journey goes on.

results.content:
I completed the entire course. Overall, I think it's a great course and I learned a lot. It seems like a very practical example of combining Bootstrap, HTML, JS, JQeury, and CSS into one functioning website.

The instructor, Drew, is also really good about answering questions quickly.

A few things folks should know before buying:
- Personally, I don't think this is a good course for people completely new to Bootstrap. Having prior knowledge of Bootstrap and being fairly comfortable using the row/col system and the grid system already would be really helpful. I took another course that was more centered on just Bootstrap, and I think that was a great foundation for this course.

My one criticism of this course:
- Section 17, the contact form section. Specifically, we are basically told to "just host the site somewhere" to get the full contact form working once we have it all set up. This is not that simple to do if you aren't familiar with hosting a PHP website already (the contact form uses PHP), and a guide on how to do this would have been extremely helpful. Hosting is covered in Section 20, but Section 17 doesn't mention that you can check out Section 20 for help.

response.content: Hi Aleksander, sorry you didn't enjoy the course but thanks for the feedback.  In the course we develop the jQuery customizations to Bootstrap components and the settings for the plugin scripts used which you mention.  The scripts that are imported are for the contact form, form validation, and a few javascript features like the image portfolio lightbox for example. The code for some of these scripts might be a 100 hour course in and of themselves so we import plugins in the course to make the website interactive as such.  Let me know if you have any questions. -Drew

response.content: Hi Jola, thanks for taking the course and adding this well-thought-out feedback!  I have heard this request once before of having more explanations of the plugins and how they operate.  Included in lectures 52 & 53 are explanations on customizing the plugin features such as the animation for example (to add your own animation style, placement, timing) but I don't have plans to explain the code in the plugin library aside from this implementation.  The available github pages for plugins (linked in the resources file)  could provide more explanation though if you wish to check them. Thanks :). -Drew

results.content: I think I stumbled across this course from a youtube video from the course instructor.  I had never done any web development before this and found it easy to follow along and create a very nice website for a project a friend of mine and I are working on.  Now I am taking more courses to improve my knowledge of HTML, JS, CSS, PHP, MySQL.  This course does a great job of giving you a starting point to get your feet wet and create something at the same time.  Many other courses teach you but by the end, all you have is the knowledge of how to create something rather than using the course to not only teach you some things but also help you create something along the way.  So far I am really impressed with every Udemy course I have taken!
